learningObject.name: Writing a Good Project Proposal
learningObject.text:
Upon completion of his internship, every SOI student must submit a project proposal. The scope of the proposal must be suitable for acceptance as a final year project.

 

 

This e-lesson provides guidelines on how to write a a good project proposal.

accNav.name: What is a Project Proposal?
accNav.text:
There is no singular, internationally accepted definition for the term "project proposal".

 

For the purpose of a proposing a final year student project, the following definition is suitable:

 

"Project proposals are documents designed to present a plan of action, outline the reasons why the action is necessary, and convince the reader to agree with and approve the implementation of the actions recommended in the body of the document" (http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-project-proposal.htm)

 

To achieve its purpose, a project proposal is organised into 7 sections. These are Company Information, Project Summary, Introduction, Current Process, Opportunities for Improvements and Benefits, Proposed Solution and Appendix.

 

A brief description on each section's purpose is presented on the right.

nestedPage.name: Company Information
nestedPage.text: Contains Information of the company that benefits from the project deliverables.

nestedPage.name: Project Summary
nestedPage.text:
Proposes a name for the project that is easily rememebered.

 

Describes the project objective(s) and benefit(s) in 3 to 5 sentences. This enables the reader to gain a apprisal of the project without having to read the entire proposal.

nestedPage.name: Introduction
nestedPage.text:
This section mainly serves 3 purposes.

 

Firstly, it describes the company in terms of the products and services that it produces. If the project is relevant to a department within the company, it will also describe the role of that department.

Secondly, it briefly describes the process that produces the products and services.  If the project is relevant to a department within the company, it will also focus on the process stages that the department is responsible for.

Lastly, it pinpoints the process stages that this project will affect and describes what are the changes that the project will bring about.

accNav.name: What is a Project Proposal?, more .....
accNav.text:
There is no singular, internationally accepted definition for the term "project proposal".

 

For the purpose of a proposing a final year student project, the following definition is suitable:

 

"Project proposals are documents designed to present a plan of action, outline the reasons why the action is necessary, and convince the reader to agree with and approve the implementation of the actions recommended in the body of the document" (http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-project-proposal.htm)

 

To achieve its purpose, a project proposal is organised into 7 sections. These are Company Information, Project Summary, Introduction, Current Process, Opportunities for Improvements and Benefits, Proposed Solution and Appendix.

 

A brief description on each section's purpose is presented on the right.

nestedPage.name: Current Process
nestedPage.text:
This section describes in detail the process stages that this project will affect. This can include the inputs, activities, schedules and resource to produce the necessary outputs.

Where useful, supplement the description with BPMN diagrams, flow charts, screen captures of present systems, sample documents etc.

nestedPage.name: Opportunities for Improvements and Benefits
nestedPage.text:
This sections describes opportunities (or needs) for improvements in the current process. The focus should be on the difference between the current state and the desired end state.

In addition, having achieved the desired end state, describe how this will improve the products/services that the company produces.

nestedPage.name: Proposed Solution
nestedPage.text:
This section describes in detail how the implementation (or enhancement) of an IT solution will play a pivotal role in realising the opportunities for improvements. It will also include sub-sections describing hardware, software, manpower resources and project milestones.

 

While not a formal design document, make use of BPMN diagrams, use cases, sequence diagrams etc. to supplement the explaination of how the IT solution will work.

nestedPage.name: Appendix
nestedPage.text: Include other useful reference materials here. These can be sample documents, reports, systems statistics, hand-written memos etc.

tabNav.name: Be  S M A R T !
tabNav.text:
Key Points to Bear in Mind When Writing a Project Proposal

  • S - Specific
  • M - Measurable
  • A - Attaintable
  • R - Relevant
  • T - Timebound

nestedPage.name: Specific
nestedPage.text:
When writing a project proposal, be specific on the following:

  • What are the key objectives of the project?
  • What are the key features of the solution?
  • What improvements or changes will the solution bring about?

Being specific will help the reader understand how the solution will look like.

 

Positive

Examples 
  • Reduce the amount of time taken for the generation of call centre performance reports and format these reports for tablet access
  • Automated data download and generation of performance reports at periodic intervals
  • Formatting of performance reports for mobile device viewing
  • Incorporation of drill-down feature to quickly understand reports in greater detail

Negative

Examples 
  • Web pages for for sales department
  • Generate reports
  • Provide administration functions
  • Improve user friendlieness

nestedPage.name: Measurable
nestedPage.text:
When writing a project proposal, define project success in measurable terms. This makes success unambiguously recognisable.

 

Where possible, for each key feature proposed define success in either qualitative or quantitative terms.

 

Qualitative terms refers to some observable, desired characteristics. Quantitative terms refers to a numerical measure.

 

 

Examples of 

Qualitative Terms
  • Web page design appeals to 30-45 age group
  • Payment interface is configurable by the adminstrator to handle all major currencies
  • Web site is secured by the use of the https protocol
  • Web application to be constructed using industry strength PHP framework

 

  Examples of Quantitative Terms
  • Application to reduce the use of paper forms by 80%
  • Automatic FAQ interface to be able to correctly answer 75% of questions asked via a free-text interface
  • Registeration for new class must be completed using a single web page
  • Booking system must be able to handle 100 concurrent users

nestedPage.name: Attainable
nestedPage.text:
A project proposal is not just about trumpeting features and benefits. It is important to be realistic on what resources are required for the features and benefits to be attainable.

 

In the context of a student FYP,  these are considerations:

 

Resource/Constraint Comments

Skills & Knowledge

Do students have the pre-requisite skills and knowlege to complete the project?

If not, can they acquire these and still deliver the project within schedule?

What help can the school or company provide to students to gain these skills and knowledge?

Manpower

Is the proposed scope too much to handle for 3 to 4 students taking into account their skills and knowledge levels?

Conversely, is the scope too little for 3 to 4 students? Bear in mind that FYP is a gradable module.

Software Licenses & Development Environments

 

Does your project require paid software licenses? Is the company able to provide/pay for these licenses?

Does your project development need to be done in the company's development environment? How will students gain access if they are working within RP?

Hardware

 

Does your project require other hardware beyond a personal computer, e.g. scanners, mobile phones, temperature detectors etc.?

How will these be made available? Can these be loan from the company, resource centre or the school?

Confidientiality Arrangements

 

Does your project require access to confidential information resources owned by the company during development? For example, database schema, test data that simulates the actual environment or company specific codes and categorisations.

What agreements must all agreed to ensure confidentiality?

nestedPage.name: Relevant
nestedPage.text:
When describing features and benefits, relate these to how the products or services produced by the company or department are improved.

 

 

Some examples:

  • The quick generation of performance reports provides the account managers with more time to analyse issues before the weekly reviews with their clients
  • The drill-down feature enables the account managers to answer adhoc queries directly from clients. They no longer need to call back to the head-office to ask for details
  • Completing all registraton procedures in one web page is projected to increase the number of registrations to 150 per hour
  • The automated FAQ feature is projected to reduce the percentage of questions requiring human attention by 7%

nestedPage.name: Timebound
nestedPage.text:
Please bear in mind that FYP needs to be completed in about 14 weeks by a 3-4 student team. The project proposal should include milestones that highlights key deliverables over this period. These milestones can be based on the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC). Realistically, over such a short period, there will only be sufficient time to cover Planning, Analysis, Design, Development & Testing. Implementation is likely limited to handing over source code and documentation to the company.

Sample High Level Project Milestones 

 

W

 SDLC Phase Key Activity(s) Key Deliverable(s)
01 Planning Confirm project scope and update business requirements Updated business requirements in free text format
02 Analysis Create use case diagram & specifications Structured and detailed business requirements with logic flow
03-05 Design Create database scheme design and prototype mock-ups.  Application designs based on thematic or technical preferences of the company
06-11 Development Coding and writing of test plan/scripts Demonstrations and progress updates as appropriate
12-13 Testing Conduct user acceptance testing Completed project
14 Assessment Prepare for assessment Project reports and related documentaion, e.g user manual
15 Implementation Hand over project Completed project inclusive of installation package and documentation.

nestedPage.name: Company
nestedPage.text:
This is a project proposal for the fictitious company Wise Owl Tutors. The left panel is the proposal content. The right panel explains the SMART (or lack of) qualities of this proposal

 

Company

Wise Owl Tutors was founded in 2010 by Mr Goo Ah Seng with a staff of 3 Mathematics tutors. Over the past 5 years, it gained a reputation for providing value-for-money service to help below-average and average students score a better grade. In 2015, Wise Owl Tutors has a staff of 15 tutors and 3 customer service officers. It offers tuition services in Mathematics, Physics, Chemistry and Science for primary, secondary and JC levels.

Its key competitors are other neighbourhood tuition centres such as Bright Squirrel Tuition Centre.

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text:
The project proposal starts of by giving a brief description of company history,  its key product(s)/service(s) and standing in the industry. it is concise and SPECIFIC.

The reference to key competitors is particularly useful if the company is not well-known.

nestedPage.name: Summary
nestedPage.text:
Project Name: Course Registration & Enquiry Management System (CREMS)

Since it started business operations, Wise Owl Tutors has relied on a paper based process to manage registrations and class schedules. With an increased business volume, it is no longer efficient to continue using this error-prone process. It is also impossible to analyse information collected to identify issues or business opportunities.

CREMS is a web-based system that aims to improve Wise Owl Tutors registration and enquiry processes.  CREMS reaches out to a much wider customer base, reduces time and effort taken for customers to enrol for tuition classes and creates a history of business transactions for analytic purposes.

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text:
The summary section starts by naming the application and giving it an easy to remember acryonym, CREMS in this case.

It then describes the key challenges the company is facing that will be addressed by the project. It then follows up with some of the objectives and features that the project delivers to address these challenges.

The summary composes of only two paragraphs and five sentences in total which takes only 1-2 minutes to read at most. It is able to do so because only RELEVANT information is being conveyed.

nestedPage.name: Introduction
nestedPage.text:
Wise Owl Tutor offers tuition services in Mathematics, Physics, Chemistry and Science for primary, secondary and JC levels. It is organised into three main departments, Administration, Tutoring Services & Customer Services. CREM primarily benefits the Administration and Customer Services.

For Administration, it is primarily in the areas of course administration and publication. CREMS will provide easy to use functionality for the creation of courses and the generation of course schedules.  Course information is for administration only, e.g. start date. IT DOES NOT include course content.  With CREMS, course information is easily updated and published to the web for reference for existing and potential customers. The course schedule is also automatically generated. These were not possible in the old process.

For Customer Services, it is primarily in the enrolment and enquiry processes. For enrolment, customers can enrol directly using the web interface. The turnaround time to be acknowledged for successful/unsuccessful registration is reduced. Enquiries are also captured in more structured manner using the web interface. Overall, the customer takes over the primarily responsibility for enrolment process while the customer service officer (CSO) concentrates mainly on handling exceptions.

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text:
This section starts with a recap of the product(s) and service(s) being produced. It briefly describes the organisational structure of the company and SPECIFICALLY states the departments affected by the project.

For each affected department, there is a brief description of its existing process and the beneficial changes that the project will bring about. the discussion stays RELEVANT only to the affected departments.

nestedPage.name: Current Process
nestedPage.text:
For learning purposes, we will only describe the current enrolment process. In the introduction, it was stated that the project will affect course administration, publication, enrolment and enquiry processes. In a real proposal, all affected processes should be described.

 

Enrolment

  1. Customer receives course information and schedule from mailbox flyers and bill board at tuition centre
  2. Customer enquires on course availability and pre-requisites. Customer fills paper enrolment form
  3. Customer Service Officer verifies enrolment form and files for safekeeping and reference

There is no need to describe in minute detail how the process works. However, it is important to highlight the areas that warrants improvement.

 

Course Administration

  1. ...........
  2. ...........
  3. ...........

Publication

  1. ...........
  2. ...........
  3. ...........

Enrolment

  1. ...........
  2. ...........
  3. ...........

Enquiry

  1. ...........
  2. ...........
  3. ...........

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text:
As this is a project proposal, it sufficient to show just key the branching decisions and exception handing that may result in a negative customer experience. In the example here, the focus is SPECIFICALLY on the key steps related to enrolment.

The same practice should be adopted as far as possible for other processes.

nestedPage.name: Opportunities for Improvements & Benefits
nestedPage.text:
Customers are not aware of updates of course information, schedule changes, course availability and pre-requisites unless they call Wise Owl Tutors. Customers are often frustrated at the point of enrolment when they realise they do not qualify due to one or more of these factors.

Making this information readily available 24X7 on a ubiquitous web interface will definitely reduce customer frustration. A 30% reduction in customers not being able to enrol successfully can be expected.

Customers often commit errors when filling up the enrolment form. These are both identified and corrected by the CSOs or remain undetected. These errors are serious enough to derail the enrolment process and deprive other customers of a place in the course.

An attractive, user-friendly interface with intuitive self-help will reduce errors. Responsibility for correctly providing enrolment rests with the customer. The customers overall will have a more satisfactory enrolment experience which is less prone to errors with a faster turn-round time. Incorrect enrolment is estimated to be reduced by 80% as many errors are prevented from happening at the point of data entry. In addition, paper costs will plummet by 90% as paper forms are redundant except in very special circumstances.

With a reduced workload, CSOs can spend more time assisting customers that require special help without neglecting the regular customers.

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text:
The key issues to be addressed are SPECIFICALLY explained.

For each issue, MEASURABLE improvements in both quantitative and qualitative terms are SPECIFICALLY spelt out.  These are also directly RELEVANT to reducing costs and improving efficiency.

An example of a quantitative improvement is 90% reduction in paper costs. An example of a qualitative improvement is CSOs being able to spend more time assisting customers that require help.

nestedPage.name: Proposed Process
nestedPage.text:
For learning purposes, we will only describe the proposed enrolment process. In the introduction, it was stated that the project will affect course administration, publication, enrolment and enquiry processes. In a real proposal, all affected processes should be described.

 

Enrolment

 

Using CREMS, customers perform the following via a web interface

  1. Customer must be registered as a member to enrol in a course
  2. Member and public views course(s) schedule, pre-requisites and availability.
  3. Member checks if he qualifies for a course based on his own course history
  4. Member registers for course without need for further assistance and receive acknowledgement and confirmation automatically
  5. Member is placed on wait list automatically as necessary and is assigned a place
  6. Member is informed automatically when there is a vacancy

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text: The same practices as documenting the current process apply. Try to be as SPECIFIC as possible to enable the reader to understand what the project will deliver.

nestedPage.name: Hardware & Software Resources
nestedPage.text: CREMS will be developed using the Cake PHP application framework and mySQL database. These are open-source software readily available for free installation. Students designated to work on CREMS are famililar with both PHP and mySQL. There is a learning curve with using Cake PHP but this should not be insurmountable. The merits of using Cake PHP are security and improved programmer productivity. Both development and production hosting will be on BestHost Cloud Services. Wise Owl Tutors currently has a hosting contract for its accounting software and will be expanding this to accomodate CREMS.

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text:
This section summarises the hardware and software resources needed for the projects. As technical resources are discussed, it needs to be SPECIFIC. 

In addition, it must also convince the reader that the personel assigned to the project can achieve mastery over the hardware and software resources to deliver the project. In this example, it explains that PHP is a technology that the students are familiar with. Likewise,  it describes how the PHP hosting environment is made available and by whom.

This reassures the reader that the project deliverables are ATTAINABLE.

nestedPage.name: Manpower Resources
nestedPage.text:
Based on estimates, CREMS requires a minimum of 90 man-days to complete. On average a 4 member student team working over 14 weeks can deliver this project. These are the assumptions:-

4 X 12 man-days (1 man-day per student per week over 12 weeks)

4 X 10 man-days (10 man-days per student per week over 2 weeks during semester break)

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text:
The emphasis is on outlining the manpower resources available SPECIFICALLY. For a FYP, this is typically 70 to 90 man-days.

Given this knowledge, the proposed solution scope should fit within the manpower resource constraint.  This reassures the reader that the project deliverables are ATTAINABLE and the TIME-BOUNDED to be completed as a FYP.

nestedPage.name: Project Milestones
nestedPage.text:
W

 SDLC Phase Key Activity(s) Key Deliverable(s)
01 Planning Confirm project scope and update business requirements Updated business requirements in free text format
02 Analysis Create use case diagram & specifications Structured and detailed business requirements with logic flow
03-05 Design Create database scheme design and prototype mock-ups.  Application designs based on thematic or technical preferences of the company
06-11 Development Coding and writing of test plan/scripts

Progress updates as appropriate

Submit application design for "Neighbourhood Business Software Competition"
12-13 Testing Conduct user acceptance testing Completed project
14 Assessment Prepare for assessment Project reports and related documentaion, e.g user manual
15 Implementation Hand over project Completed project inclusive of installation package and documentation.

nestedPage.name: What is SMART about this section?
nestedPage.text:
A tabulation of key project activities and milestones gives a good appreciation of the ATTAINABILITY within TIME-BOUND constraints.

The generic SDLC phases activities serve as an useful start point. However, to increase the RELEVANCE of the proposal, important deliverables to the company should also be included. For example, "Submit application design for 'Neighbourhood Business Software Competition'"

summary.name: Recap ..... What is Important in a Project Proposal?
summary.nextsteps: Wait no further. Start writing your project proposal NOW!
summary.summary:
The project proposal's objective is to convince the reader to agree with and approve the actions recommended. In order to do this, these actions must be presented in an organised manner comprising of the following sections:

Company, Summary, Introduction, Current Process, Opportunities for Improvements & Benefits, Proposed Solution & Appendix

 

  When producing each of these sections, do it the SMART way. There is no fixed protocol for dictating which SMART quality applies for which section.  However, not being SMART typically results in a less convincing project proposal. Therefore be SMART!
